awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Arctic Hydrological Regime Shift in a Warming Climate
awd_abstract_narration:
The Arctic is currently warming faster than any other region of the globe, and recent changes in climate and hydrology have had direct impacts in Svalbard, where flash flooding and enhanced mass movement over frozen ground on steep slopes has occasionally led to catastrophic slope failure. This study will examine how warming is leading to a new hydrological regime in regions adjacent to the areas where major sea-ice losses have occurred. The new hydrological regime is result of an increase in annual precipitation, a higher proportion of which is in the form of rain rather than snow, especially in the transition seasons of fall and spring. Under this collaborative project, the team will study annually laminated sediments in lakes of western Svalbard (Norwegian Arctic) to identify the sedimentary signal of recent changes in hydrology and use this to reconstruct the long-term history of rainfall-related sedimentary events to determine when similar conditions may have prevailed in the past. This project will involve a postdoctoral scientist, a graduate student, and undergraduate students at University of Massachusetts and Bates College, as well as teacher in the research. There is training of STEM teachers through a summer program enabling them to incorporate Arctic earth science activities into their classroom curricula. 

This project will examine how warming is leading to a new hydrological regime in regions adjacent to the areas where major sea-ice losses have occurred. The investigators will study annually laminated sediments in lakes of western Svalbard to identify the sedimentary signal of recent changes in hydrology and reconstruct the long-term history of rainfall-related sedimentary events to determine when similar conditions may have prevailed in the past. The type and amount of sediment transported to lakes carries with it information about meteorological and hydrological conditions in the lake watershed. The investigators will recover sediment cores to study the structure and grain size profiles of recent years of sediment accumulation, to compare with meteorological measurements, sediment recovered in traps, and measurements of processes responsible for sediment transport and deposition. They will employ microanalytcal techniques for high-resolution grain size analysis, varve detection and measurement. Using scanning electron microscope image analysis methods, they will reconstruct rainfall-driven sedimentary events. Sediments acquired from sediment traps will be analyzed using a laser particle size analyzer to obtain sub-annual scale grain size profiles to compare with observed hydroclimatic events and the varved records. This will provide a unique perspective on the nature of recent sedimentary changes and provide insight into the effects of contemporary changes in climate on the hydrological regime of this region. The results will have implications for other parts of the Arctic where sea-ice is rapidly receding.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In a warming world, it is predicted that the Arctic will experience more rainfall instead of snowfall. However, the occurrence of rain in the region will still be influenced by natural variations on a seasonal and yearly basis. Svalbard, an archipelago in the Arctic, is particularly susceptible to changes in the amount of precipitation (its hydroclimate) because it is influenced by the northern extent of the warm North Atlantic Current. Hence, compared to other High-Arctic areas from the same latitude, climate in Svalbard is warmer and wetter and serves as a natural laboratory to study long-term hydroclimate variability. However, there are very few long measurement records from Svalbard, which would be helpful to give some perspective on recent climatic changes. To address this, we focused research on Linn?vatnet, a lake in western Spitsbergen, and examined a sediment core from the bottom of the lake, which has recorded how climate in the area has changed over the last 2,000 years.

 Before investigating the lake sediments for information about past climate (paleoclimate), we analyzed the sources of sediments entering Linn?vatnet. Samples collected from around the lake indicate that the primary sources are minor streams that pass over carbonate rocks on the eastern valley wall, and the main glacial river system (Linn?elva), which flows over coal-bearing sandstone. By employing a technique called micro-X-ray fluorescence (?-XRF), we found that calcium is the most prominent component of sediment deposited in the basin close to the river delta, where the sedimentary record was obtained. Measurements of organic content showed an inverse relationship with calcium and the magnetic properties of the sediment. This suggests that the sediment being deposited at the site of the sediment core is influenced by alternating contributions of calcium from carbonates in the eastern slopes and coal-bearing sandstone from Linn?elva. Linn?elva receives its water primarily from snow and the glacier meltwaters of Linn?breen, a small valley glacier now situated 7 km south of Linn?vatnet. Since Linn?breen is underlain by the coal-bearing sandstone, the organic content in the lake sediments of Linn?vatnet can serve as an indicator of glacier activity. 

 Using weather data recorded at the airport over the last ~120 years, our study found a strong correlation between annual changes in calcium content and grain size, and temperature and precipitation. This relationship was also persistent in the past because our record is significantly correlated to the nearby Lomonosovfonna ice core oxygen isotope record (which is related to temperature and extends back over 1000 years), as well as reconstructed winter temperatures of the Northern Hemisphere over the last millennium, obtained from a computer model simulation. Of particular interest was the fact that the coarsest grain size, highest calcium values, and lowest concentration of organics were all observed in recent years, indicating that the influence of glaciers on the sedimentary input to Linn?vatnet is currently at an unprecedented low, compared to the past millennia.

We also investigated the role of natural variability on Svalbard climate, using observations, paleo data and computer models, to understand how wet and warm weather extremes in this region have evolved over the past two thousand years. We discovered a connection between these extremes and the presence of high pressure (atmospheric blocking) patterns over the Scandinavian region or the Ural Mountains. When these blocking patterns occur, they lead to episodes of rainfall in Svalbard. The intense rainfall and stream flow carries coarse particles and high levels of calcium from the eastern carbonate slopes of Linn?vatnet, which get deposited in the lake. The coarsest sediments collected in sediment traps (devices that are suspended at depth in the lake) since 2004 are consistently found during these periods of atmospheric blocking. Importantly, these recent blocking events like the one in Fall 2016 led to the evacuation of parts of Longyearbyen, Svalbard?s capital, while the one in Decmber 2015 triggered avalanches that buried 10 houses and killed two people. 

Through our studies of a 5m long sediment record from Linn?vatnet, we have identified a persistent link between atmospheric blocking and wet conditions in Svalbard over the past 1,500 years. Furthermore, the research indicates that a long-term decline in precipitation in Svalbard since the Medieval era came to an end in the mid-19th century. In fact, the region has experienced several unprecedented and damaging extreme weather events in recent years. As the planet continues to warm and sea ice diminishes, we can expect that future flooding events in Svalbard will become even more intense during episodes of atmospheric blocking over Scandinavia or the Ural Mountains. This research underscores the importance of understanding these connections to better prepare for the hydroclimatic changes that lie ahead in the region. As our world continues to warm, it is crucial to monitor the impacts of these changes on vulnerable Arctic ecosystems and communities like those in Svalbard.
